Mental Stats

Are mental stats worth putting ingame? Some interesting points were brought up in a planeshift forum thread by Under the Moon: Link Here

This made me consider whether or not it would be a good idea to keep unenforceable mental stats.

Mental stats may not be strictly enforceable (per; low int characters talking like they have PHDs), however they can have game-effects that are as clear as physical stats. Especially in a system where NPCs have response-trees instead of typed-string-replys, sharply limiting the replys available to a character with low wis/int/cha is completely possible. Similarly, making it difficult for them to recieve much benefit from entire skills and skill groups is also possible. If a player wants to create a damage-generating machine that has no mechanical social capacity, it is entirely possible to forclose their ability to do anything but wander the game world looking for bigger fights and spending exorbatent amounts of income to get basic equipment. Darker Dreams 08:12, 12 December 2007 (CET)
After reading part of the thread I want to pull out (and add) a few points as particularly sterling;
  • Int-type stats limiting the "clues" made available to puzzles.
  • Int-type stats providing advantages in mini-games.
  • Both Int and Cha type stats "unlocking" better replies/conversation paths.
  • Cha providing different NPC reactions to certain conversation paths (Reply option; "Nice shoes." gets a hostile reaction for characters with low Cha and a pleased reaction for those with high Cha.)
  • Cha effecting bartering ability (merchant valuation of goods you wish to buy/sell). Int effecting your own ability to evaluate the worth of goods.
  • A nifty (far future) possibility is PC "creation" of NPCs (through hiring/employment/whatever). A Cha-style stat would effect the cost, quality, loyalty, and ability to get away with "delaying paychecks."
  • Derive max group size from a Charisma stat.
I'll be the first to acknowledge that enforcement of "mental stats" in a P<->P setting is entirely impossible. However, enforcement of physical stats is only possible because we have allowed the rules to make it so. Agility would become entirely irrelivant if we made a FPS-style combat engine. The question is not "what can we enforce and what isn't worth enforcing" so much as "what provides the balance/feel/environment that is desired" and creating the mechanics to fit.Darker Dreams 08:37, 12 December 2007 (CET)
